newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - U.S. technology trade publications.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - U.S. technology trade publications.

text.p: For the week of June 30, here are some of the top stories reported in major U.S. technology trade publications.

PC WEEK - Microsoft Corp's web site is frustrating users because of a sluggish performance and a recent crash of the system as a result of a hacker. Although the company is tacklng the growing pains, it also is about to add power-draining features like push and personalization, PC Week said in its June 30 edition.

The merger of Compaq Computer Corp and Tandem Computers Inc will bring Windows NT into the enterprise much faster, while it looks to move Unix out, PC Week said. Tandem, which is charged with developing scalable Windows NT technology, expects to push NT into the enterprise 18 months to 24 months faster than before the merger, PC Week said.

COMPUTERWORLD - Xylan Corp is developing a high-speed networking option called Gigabit Token Ring that offers users an alternative to migrating from token ring LANs to Ethernet-based technologies. The company plans to ship the switches and uplinks by the end of the year, ComputerWorld reported in its June 30 issue.

The shortage in the information systems field is going to last for the next six years and will cost companies about $15 billion a year in compensation costs. It also could cost $500 billion a year in lost revenue from uncompleted projects, ComputerWorld said.

COMPUTER RESELLER NEWS - Netscape Communications Corp is developing a Java-based browser for the network computer, signaling a shift in its client strategy and an attempt to move into non-Microsoft Corp territory, Computer Reseller News reported June 30.

After two years of hype, the reality of developing in Sun Microsystems Inc's Java language is starting to sink in, especially among ISVs that gambled heavily on Java to reinvigorage their application efforts, CRN reported June 30. Corel Corp has once again pushed back the debut of its Corel Office for Java until October.

INFOWORLD - Netscape is building a content framework meant to revolutionize Web-site display into its next generation Apollo server and Mercury client Web products, which are due in early 1998, InfoWorld reported June 30.

Customers and analysts appear to be giving Compaq Computer Corp's bid to acquire Tandem Computers Inc an initial thumbs up as Compaq prepares to compete in the high-end server market with IBM, H-P and Digital Equipment Corp, InfoWorld reported June 30.

INFORMATION WEEK - Microsoft is picking up its pace to deliver mobile network computing to the enterprise and on September 29 it will introduce a series of technologies and operating system upgrades designed to bring $500 mobile network computing devices to corporate users, Information Week reported June 30.

President Clinton will declare this week that private enterprise, not governments, must lead the world into global electronic commerce and he will advocate making the Internet an untaxed, duty-free zone for the buying and selling of digital products, Information Week reported June 30.

EE TIMES - As the giant digital clock in Bejing's infamous Tiananmen Square counts off the hours, minutes and seconds to Hong Kong's momentus handover to China at midnight June 30, the question on everyone's mind is what sort of hybrid culture the reunification will engender.

But for engineers inside the People's Republic, the question is much more personal, will their standard of living and working conditions rise to the level of their peers in Hong Kong or will the inertia of the mainlamd keep them poorly paid and threatened with chronic unemployment, EE Times reported June 30.
ELECTRONIC BUYERS' NEWS - Time is running out for two distributors -- Avnet Inc and Kent Electronics Corp -- who have not agreed to comply with AMP Inc line-card policy.

AMP's new policy requires the distributors to carry no more than six competitive connector lines, two major and four minor. But the distributos who have complied say AMP is getting easier to do business with, Electronic Buyers' News reported in its June 30 edition.

INTERACTIVE WEEK - A Perot Systems Inc subsidiary has agreed to acquire Nets Inc.'s assets and intellectual property and has already hired 58 formers Nets Inc engineers. The company, run by former Lotus Development CEO Jim Manzi, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on May 9. Manzi, who was covering Nets Inc expenses of $500,000 a week out of his own pocket for nearly a month, has filed a $1.7 million secured claim against Nets, Interactive Week reported June 30.
